action.action-desc: Ms. Slotkin (for herself and Mr. Wittman) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Armed Services

form.official-title: To authorize the provision of non-medical counseling services to a member of the Armed Forces, or a dependent of such member, by a mental health professional, without regard to the location of the provider or recipient of such services.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Comforting Our Military Families through On-base or Remote Treatment Act or the COMFORT Act.

section.header: Non-medical counseling services for military families

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a mental health professional described in subsection (b) may provide non-medical counseling services to military families at any location in a State, the District of Columbia, or a territory or possession of the United States, without regard to where the provider or recipient of such services is located, if the provision of such services is within the scope of the authorized Federal duties of the provider.
A mental health professional described in this subsection is a person who is—

paragraph.text: a currently licensed or certified mental health care provider who holds an unrestricted license or certification that is—

subparagraph.text: issued by a State, the District of Columbia, or a territory or possession of the United States; and
recognized by the Secretary of Defense;

paragraph.text: a member of the Armed Forces, a civilian employee of the Department of Defense, or a contractor designated by the Secretary; and
performing authorized duties for the Department of Defense under a program or activity referred to in subsection (a).
